nodes.bodyText: Maybe PushDistinctLimitAsAggregationIntoTableScan
No, i don't think so.
rnn?
We do no seem to have practice of adorning a rule with comments what other rules may or may not do with the plan output from the rule?
I see, but this is quite unintuitive that rule says that it is pushing distinct limit, while actually it pushes only distinct.
Thanks
Rule unit tests?

Table scan pushdowns are hard to test "normally".
I wanted to copy tests from PushAggregationIntoTableScan (#3697) but can't find them (#5812). cc @martint
Looking into it.
This is not much readable, please extract local variable, just before aggregationPushdownResult

However, having a variable is flaky, if the content is conditional -- note that previously we used those assignments instead of tableScan.getAssignments and now it would not be correct.

I kinda agree with @kokosing here. I do not see a straight benefit of handling special case of empty aggregateFunctions here.
Maybe we should just always filter the assignments map, so we only pass to applyAggregation those which are needed by any of the aggregations in list?

nodes.bodyText: It is single threaded, no need to have atomic here
require non null applyAggregation? To make sure it is always set in test.
The test code ensures -- and must ensure that -- thru the way how assertions are written.
nit: doesNotFire is kinda misleading here. As rule is fired. Yet it returns empty() so it does nothing.
pre existing,

empty() so it does nothing.

A rule returning empty() means "it didn't fire". Firing means that the rule resulted in some transformation of the plan.

Before we had patterns -- the meaning was obvious.
With patterns -- the naming is no longer obvious, and i see @losipiuk 's point.
If you remember that pattern is an optional thing and rule may or may not use it (kind of), it becomes clearer -- but there is no way to get this thinking from the code.
I am OK with changing the method name if we can propose something better, but that would fall out of scope of this PR anyway.

Patterns or no patterns, it's the same. Some things cannot be represented by patterns and need to matched manually. The pattern is just a convenience mechanism, but it doesn't mean that if the pattern matches the rule "fires".
I thing you're confusing "fires" with "is invoked".
In JMX stats for optimizer rules we use "hits" and "misses" counter. Fire does not mean hit.
Yes, fire means hit. Any time a rule returns non-empty, we tick the "hits" counter. Otherwise, we tick the "misses" counter. The "invocations" counter gets ticked in either case.

I thing you're confusing "fires" with "is invoked".

i am under impression in some contexts (not here), these are used interchangeably.
Perhaps replacing  "fires" with "applies" would provide for more obvious terminology.

i am under impression in some contexts (not here), these are used interchangeably.

Can you give an example? I'm not aware of any such cases.
I meant spoken "dev english", not the Presto code base.

Fire does not mean hit.



Yes, fire means hit

Surely, I am not an english speaker. But if a bullet is fired (launched), it does mean it will hit the target. Hence "fire" is closer for me in the meaning to "invocations". But I get used to it the current Presto glossary.
